newsitem.title: ZIMBABWE: Africa bank chief urges removal of trade barriers.
newsitem.headline: Africa bank chief urges removal of trade barriers.

text.p: An African bank formed to promote trade within and outside the world's poorest continent urged governments on the continent on Tuesday to remove barriers obstructing intra-African trade.
African Export-Import Bank (Afreximbank) president Christopher Edordu said tariff and non-tariff barriers had largely contributed to a five percent decline in intra-African trade in 1996.

He told the bank's annual general meeting in Harare that African tariffs stood at an average level of about 27 percent, much higher than those in industrialised countries and the newly industrialising states of south-east Asia.

"The decline in intra-African trade which has been ascribed to growing tariff and non-tariff barriers represents a crucial challenge to our policy makers who clearly could not have participated in establishing a vast array of co-operation arrangements only to mutually stall those...," Edordu said.
"Our hope is that our continental institutions and national authorities would move to remove the obstacles rapidly," he said.
African trade also declined as a proportion of global trade, to 2.4 percent compared to 3.1 percent in 1995, he added.
"Indeed the decline in African trade may have been worse but for robust increases in export volumes which moderated the potential effect of lower commodity prices," he said.
Zimbabwe's Finance Minister Herbert Murerwa, while lauding the Afreximbank for financing exports from several African states, urged greater focus on intra-Africa trade to help economic integration.
The Cairo-based Afreximbank was established in 1993 by African governments, private investors and national and regional financial institutions to help expand intra- and extra-African trade.
It extends pre- and post-shipment financing, export credit guarantees and project-related financing.
